docs.text: i was originally going to give the spanish prisoner two and half stars .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: from my first viewing , i noticed that david mamet's film was intense and clever at times but boring and cliched at other times especially at the beginning .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: from my second viewing however , i noticed that mamet's script was actually a masterpiece .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the spanish prisoner , like the usual suspects or chinatown , begs for the viewer's complete attention .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: miss a scene or even a small detail , and you could miss the meaning of the entire film .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: also like the aforementioned films , it rewards its viewer for paying attention by delivering a surprising and memorable ending .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: mamet is success doing again what he once tackled in 1987 when he wrote and directed house of games .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: like his past gem , the spanish prisoner fools the audience as much ( or even more ) than the victim .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: because we were deceived just like the victim , we feel a strong attachment to the main character and consequently are more interested in the film .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: mamet has the talent of not completely ending a film gift wrapped , but rather leaving some ambiguity towards the end .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the power that he has in forcing the viewer to determine who the good guys and bad guys are once the film is over , without giving a right answer , is unique and ingenious .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the spanish prisoner will leave you seriously puzzled and intrigued .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: after seeing the film again , i noticed that the details mamet uses are so incredibly accurate it is frightening .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his direction is very subtle ; as he leaves so many clues explaining what is going on and who is who but it is still very difficult to tell what exactly is happening even if you see all of them , or think you see all of them .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the story follows a young up and coming businessman , joe ross , ( campbell scott ) who has just created a mysterious and lucrative " process " that everyone is trying to get their hands on .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: soon ross does not know who he can trust or who is after his " process . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: through his journey ross meets a number of mysterious characters : the rich and popular jimmy dell , a secretary who has a huge crush on ross , and ross' boss mr . klein .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: played by steve martin , rebecca pidgeon , and ben gazarra respectively , the supporting cast is very solid especially martin , who deserved an oscar nomination for his commanding and manipulative role .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the most interesting character in the film , though , was campbell scott's joe ross .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the character's transformation from an ingenuous and polite rookie to a paranoid veteran is very apparent and justifiable .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: david mamet's script is so interesting because we know people don't actually talk like the characters in the film , yet we feel so connected to some of them .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his beguiling style could fool any viewer up for the challenge .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is a must see , for those interested in solving a complex puzzle of a movie .
docs.label: positive
